<details><summary>Decrease in tech debt: (relative, absolute) = (70.00, 0.02)</summary>

|Current number|Change|Type|
|-:|:-:|:-|
|3216|-70|porting notes|

Current commit [2a863c025b](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/2a863c025bc5c81ab44b74740662c9f1f0db25df)
Reference commit [ab1d2f2636](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/ab1d2f26368cf02cd79b996f5dcb997d576e96e5)

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
Looks mostly reasonable to me, but a few questions.
Looks mostly reasonable to me, but a few questions.
I don't know what this means

We've to decided to keep these. This particular one isn't used anywhere, but the others in the family are used at various points to avoid universe unification failures. No need to keep a porting note.
But I'll separately investigate whether we really need them still. Things have changed since we worked out this trick.
I think it's fine to ignore this since we're tracking `erw` debt separately.
Does this not still indicate a problem?
Not really. There are many subtle changes in what works by reducible rfl.
